qas.question: What were the two Huguenot neighborhoods created in Berlin?

answers.text: in protest against the occupation of Prussia by Napoleon

qas.question: What years did this occupation take place?

answers.text: Fredericia (Denmark), Berlin, Stockholm, Hamburg, Frankfurt, Helsinki, and Emden

context: In Berlin, the Huguenots created two new neighbourhoods: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b6_0>Dorotheenstadt<b6_0/> and <b7_0>Friedrichstadt<b7_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. By <b8_0>1700<b8_0/>, <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b9_0>one-fifth<b9_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> of the city's population was French speaking. The Berlin Huguenots preserved the French language in their church services for nearly a century. They ultimately decided to switch to German <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>in protest<a2_1/> against the occupation of Prussia by Napoleon<a2_2/><a2_0/> in <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b5_0>1806<b5_0/>-07<a3_2/><a3_0/>.<a3_1/> Many of their descendents rose to positions of prominence. Several congregations were founded, such as those of <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>Fredericia (Denmark), Berlin, Stockholm, Hamburg, Frankfurt, Helsinki, and Emden<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
